brief_summary.textblock: Postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) refers to the difficulties of orientation, cognition, communication, memory and abstract thinking of patients after anesthesia and surgery. And/or accompanied by the decline of the ability in social activities, such as the change of personality, social ability of language and behavior, cognitive function and life skills. POCD is a common complication of central nervous system in elderly patients after operation, with an early incidence of about 21% and a long-term incidence of about 35% . According to the current research on Alzheimer's disease (AD) and POCD in the elderly, it has been found that they have similar pathological basis and some homologous related genes. Altogether, POCD is closely related to molecular pathway neuropsychiatric diseases (such as dementia, depression and Alzheimer's disease). Researchers have come up with various hypotheses to reveal the underlying mechanisms of POCD, including neuritis, oxidative stress, autophagy disorder, synaptic dysfunction, and lack of neurotrophic support. To date, apart from evaluating with scales, CT Scan and EEG analysis, there is neither exact biomarkers for monitoring and diagnosing POCD, nor clear relationships between specific EEG changes and diagnosis of POCD, so that the diagnosis of early POCD only stays in the evaluation of clinical symptoms and scales. Therefore, our study aims to provide an effective basis for early diagnosis and treatment of clinical POCD through multivariate analyses of clinical scales combined with EEG analysis of patients.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Patients in the control group were followed up without POCD postoperatively.
arm_group.description: According to the cognitive function scales and 3D-CAM scale associated with delirium, the corresponding scores are obtained to comprehensively judge whether there is postoperative cognitive dysfunction. Cognitive function scales including Hopkins Verbal Learning Test Retention (HVLTRet), Hopkins Verbal Learning Total Recall(HVLTTR), the Brief Visuospatial Memory Test Total Recall (BVMTTR), Brief Visuospatial Memory Test Delayed Recall (BVMTDR), Brief Visuospatial Memory Test, Total Learning, Brief Visuospatial Memory Test Retention, the Benton Judgment of Line Orientation (JLO), and Trail Making B (Trails B).

study_pop.textblock: Our research is a single center, nested case-control study. Preoperatively collect the information of the elderly patients over 60 years old without undergoing craniocerebral operations, including the vital signs, the examination reports and other related data after excluding the factors that can't be included in the group. The patients' health scales and preoperative cognitive function scales were evaluated.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Elderly patients with ASA I-II who are 60 yr or older and have not undergone craniocerebral operations.
- Ability to listen, speak, understand and cooperate with neuropsychological tests, and Chinese is the mother language.
- Patients sign the informed consent form.
- Follow-up is possible.
- The liver and kidney function, cardiopulmonary function are normal or compensatory.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who have been diagnosed with AD.
- Patients who can't cooperate with the evaluation of the cognitive scales preoperatively and the corresponding scores are abnormal.
- Patients who have been diagnosed with delirium before surgery.
- Being taking antidepressants or sedatives, and being dependent on drugs or alcohol.
- Patients who plan to undergo carotid artery, intracranial and cardiac surgery
- Have undergone one or more operations within six months.
- Have had participated in other clinical researches within six months.
